liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics says the total number of homes commencing construction rose 14 per cent from December to March seasonally adjusted. That's the biggest percentage increase since the June quarter 2021. However, housing starts are down 6.6 per cent from March last year. In terms of houses, building commencement was down 5.5 per cent over the March quarter to a two and a half year low, while apartment starts jumped 57 per cent to 19,344. CommSec says work started on 179,427 new homes over the 12 months to March this year, down by one fifth. Housing starts are down from a record high of 234,440 dwellings in June 2016. And that's why there is a housing crisis. In this graph you can see how much dwelling starts have fallen since mid 2021.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Not enough homes being built

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics says the total number of homes commencing construction rose 14 per cent from December to March seasonally adjusted.
That's the biggest percentage increase since the June quarter 2021.
However, housing starts are down 6.6 per cent from March last year.
In terms of houses, building commencement was down 5.5 per cent over the March quarter to a two and a half year low, while apartment starts jumped 57 per cent to 19,344.
CommSec says work started on 179,427 new homes over the 12 months to March this year, down by one fifth.
Housing starts are down from a record high of 234,440 dwellings in June 2016.
And that's why there is a housing crisis.
In this graph you can see how much dwelling starts have fallen since mid 2021.

props.alt: Graph showing housing starts since March 2015

children.content: Home starts
(ABS)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier today New Zealand's Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold at 5.5 per cent after 12 rate hikes in a row since late 2021. Capital Economics Australian and New Zealand economist Abhijit Surya says it was a surprise to no one. "The RBNZ's decision to leave its official cash rate on hold at 5.5 per cent was widely expected. "The minutes of the July meeting reinforce our view that the bank's tightening cycle is over." Surya says the central bank noted higher interest rates were "constraining domestic spending as expected" in a nod to the recession caused by the steep hike in official rates. And he suggest that rate cuts could be on the cards next year. "Although the bank implied that rate cuts would be unlikely before the second half of 2024, we think the combination of a deepening recession and easing price pressures will pave the way for an easing cycle as early as Q1 2024 (the first quarter of next year). New Zealand lifted interest rates by 5.25 per cent over 20 months in the most aggressive tightening since the official cash rate was introduced in 1990.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is NZ's rate hiking cycle over?

children.content: Earlier today New Zealand's Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold at 5.5 per cent after 12 rate hikes in a row since late 2021.
Capital Economics Australian and New Zealand economist Abhijit Surya says it was a surprise to no one.
"The RBNZ's decision to leave its official cash rate on hold at 5.5 per cent was widely expected.
"The minutes of the July meeting reinforce our view that the bank's tightening cycle is over."
Surya says the central bank noted higher interest rates were "constraining domestic spending as expected" in a nod to the recession caused by the steep hike in official rates.
And he suggest that rate cuts could be on the cards next year.

"Although the bank implied that rate cuts would be unlikely before the second half of 2024, we think the combination of a deepening recession and easing price pressures will pave the way for an easing cycle as early as Q1 2024 (the first quarter of next year).
New Zealand lifted interest rates by 5.25 per cent over 20 months in the most aggressive tightening since the official cash rate was introduced in 1990.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has confirmed RBA governor Philip Lowe will travel with him to India next week for a meeting of the G20. Lowe’s term is set to end in September, and his future is uncertain, as the federal government considers whether to extend his term or replace him. Chalmers has said he will make that decision this month, but he confirmed Lowe would attend the G20 meeting with him. Chalmers said Lowe needed no introduction to the world stage, having made significant contributions in his role. "He and I will work closely together to represent Australia's interest in that forum and also to make our contribution to the big global conversation about how we safeguard our economies from inflation," Chalmers said. By political reporter Nicole Hegarty
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer and RBA governor to travel to India for G20 meeting

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has confirmed RBA governor Philip Lowe will travel with him to India next week for a meeting of the G20.
Lowe’s term is set to end in September, and his future is uncertain, as the federal government considers whether to extend his term or replace him.
Chalmers has said he will make that decision this month, but he confirmed Lowe would attend the G20 meeting with him.
Chalmers said Lowe needed no introduction to the world stage, having made significant contributions in his role.

"He and I will work closely together to represent Australia's interest in that forum and also to make our contribution to the big global conversation about how we safeguard our economies from inflation," Chalmers said.
By political reporter Nicole Hegarty
